Authors: Segula Masaphy, Limor Zabari, Doron Goldberg
Title:
New long season ecotype of Morchella rufobrunnea from
northern Israel
Abstract:
True morel ascocarps commonly appear in spring for a
limited period of a few weeks over the world. There has been only one
earlier report of a morel population, presumably mycorrhizal, persisting
for several months at a single site from Israel. The present study
describes a new pioneer type that fruited in northern Israel from early
November to late May (winter and spring). The new ecotype, Morchella
rufobrunnea (MS2-IL), was identified using the sequence of the nuclear
ribosomal internal transcribed spacer and is reported for the first time
out of the American Continent. Its population size was monitored from
2001 to 2006 and correlated with concurrently collected rainfall and
temperature data. This constitutes the first report of a sighting of M.
rufobrunnea in Israel and the second report describing long season
morels anywhere in the world.
